monogr.title: The hekatompathia or Passionate centurie of loue : diuided into two parts: whereof, the first expresseth the authors sufferance in loue: the latter, his long farewell to loue and all his tyrannie. Composed by Thomas Watson Gentleman; and published at the request of certaine gentlemen his very frendes
monogr.author: Watson, Thomas

div.head: A Quatorzain, in the commendation of Master Thomas Watson, and of his Mistres, for whom he wrote this Booke of Passionat Sonnetes.
div.l: THe starr's, which did at Petrarch's byrthday raigne,
Were fixt againe at thy natiuity,
Who skald the skies in lofty Quatorzain,
The Muses gaue to thee thy fatall vaine,
The very same, that Petrarch had, whereby
Madonna Laures same is growne so by,
And that whereby his glory he did gaine.
Thou hast a Laure, whom well tho • dost commend,
And to her praise thy passion songs do tend;
Yee both such praise deserue, as naught can smother;
In briefe with Petrarch and his Laure in grace
Thou and thy Dame be equall, saue percase
Thou passe the one, and • heexcell's the other.
